p: Rolta et al. examined the antimicrobial effects of methanolic and petroleum ether extracts of A. annua on drug-resistant bacteria and fungi alone and in combination with antibiotics. Bacterial strains are more sensitive to Candida strains than to the bacteriostatic activity of these extracts, according to the results of their experiment. These extracts had a synergistic effect when combined with antibacterial and antifungal antibiotics, lowering MICs by 4-264 times against bacterial ( S. aureus and E. coli) and Candida strains and increasing inhibitory activity. Using the diffusion method, none of these extracts showed antimicrobial activity against E. coli (ATCC25922) or S. aureus (ATCC29213), but methanolic extracts with MIC = 0.125 mg/ml and ether extract with MIC = 0.65 mg/ml inhibited both bacteria. In essential oil, thirteen compounds were identified, none of which were comparable to the essential oil compounds detected in this study [ 48].
